titleStmt.title: Articles of impeachment exhibited against Col. Robert Gibbons and Cap. Richard Yeardley, late governors of the Isle of Jersey; wherein the several impeachments, notorious actions, high misdemeanours, abominations and oppressions, are laid open, detected, and made publick to the admiring world; as also, a remedy for the people, against the heavy yoke of such tyrannical oppressours, in this juncture of miraculous restauration, after so long a bondage, wherein the little finger of some appeared heavier then the whole loins of others.
titleStmt.author: Gibbons, Robert.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 33 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 9 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Articles of impeachment exhibited against Col. Robert Gibbons and Cap. Richard Yeardley, late governors of the Isle of Jersey; wherein the several impeachments, notorious actions, high misdemeanours, abominations and oppressions, are laid open, detected, and made publick to the admiring world; as also, a remedy for the people, against the heavy yoke of such tyrannical oppressours, in this juncture of miraculous restauration, after so long a bondage, wherein the little finger of some appeared heavier then the whole loins of others.
titleStmt.author: Gibbons, Robert.
A. B.
Yeardley, Richard.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for G. Horton, living near Cripplegate,

notesStmt.note: Editor's introductory letter dated and signed: Jersey 24. of June 1659, A.B.
Reproductions of the originals in the Huntington Library (Early English books 163:6) and the British Library (Thomason Tracts E.989[20]).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2011-01 Megan MarionText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: Articles of Impeachment Exhibited again≈øt Col. ROBERT GIBBONS AND Cap. RICHARD YEARDLEY, Late Governors of the I≈øle of Jer≈øey;
WHEREIN The ≈øeveral Impeachments, notorious Actions, high Mi≈ødemeanours, Abominations and Oppre≈ø≈øions, are laid open, detected, and made publick to the Admiring World;

AS ALSO, A Remedy for the People, again≈øt the Heavy Yoke of ≈øuch Tyrannical Oppre≈øsours, in this Juncture of Miraculous Re≈øtauration, after ≈øo long a Bondage, wherein the Little Finger of ≈øome appeared heavier then the whole Loins of others.
London, Printed for G. Horton, living near Cripplegate, 1659.

I Have taken the opportunity, by a Boat now going for England, with Mr Pemell, the Chirurgion of this Garri≈øon, who is ≈øent with an Addre≈øs of the Souldiery here, to the Lord Fleetwood, and Council of the Army, to let you know, that without difficulty, you cannot imagine how much the dejected, almost dying ≈øpirits of the well-affected people of this I≈øle have been revived, and the joy they have had by that unexpected, and almost miraculous re≈øtauration of the famous long-Parliament, to the exerci≈øe (once again) of their ≈øupreme trusts, from which they had been ≈øo long interrupted. And that which hath added to their joy and content, is the Advice we have received from London, which doth intimate to us, that there is very great probability, that the people of this poor I≈øland (after their long bondage and mi≈øery,) will be delivered from the heavy yoak of their pre≈øent oppre≈ø≈øors, to wit, from Col. Robert Gibbons, and Captain Richard Yeardley his Deputy, who, we are credibly informed, appeared in London, and el≈øewhere, notorious enemies to that happy re≈øtauration. It is here affirmed, that Lieut. Col. Ma≈øon, is in nomination to be our Governour: we hear a very good report of him, and that he is a profe≈ø≈øed enemy to Tyranny. In ca≈øe he doth take care to have Officers under him, that may be thus qualified, it will be an honour to him, and great ≈øatisfaction to all the faithful of this place, who have very much ≈øuffered under the others; and would have imfallably ≈øuffered in a higher degree, in ca≈øe this ≈øudden alteration of things had not happened: the Bayliff and others being very much threatned, and that onely for having ≈øigned a Procuration here to ≈øome of their faithful Patriots in London, which tended onely for the good and ≈øafety of the whole I≈øland. Benjamin Dumare≈øy, the late Protector's Atturney General in this I≈øle, was very active again≈øt the ≈øaid Bayliff, and others well affected, in oppo≈øing the ≈øame in the
behalf (as he pretended) of his Ma≈øter the Protector, and the ≈øaid Gibbons and Yeardley, to who≈øe ≈øervice he was very zealous again≈øt the publick good.

Having ≈øeen by divers good things publi≈øht in print, that there are yet (after ≈øo long Apo≈øtacy) ≈øome hopes of just liberty, it hath encouraged me to ≈øend you here inclo≈øed, tho≈øe Articles of high mi≈ødemeanours again≈øt the ≈øaid Gibbons and Yeardley, who (in the life of the old Protector, ≈øo called) were ≈øent to the Pre≈øident of his Council; but nothing being done therein, 'tis judged fit, not onely by my ≈øelf, but by ≈øeveral other honest people of this I≈øle, that they might be made publick; for the performance of which, I leave it to your Judgement and Di≈øcretion, remaining

closer.signed: Honoured Sir, Your affectionate Friend and Servant, A. B.

div.head: Articles of mi≈ødemeanours, exhibited again≈øt Col. Rob: Gibbons, Governour of the I≈øle of Jer≈øey.
div.p:
1. THat contrary to the ancient Charters and Priviledges of that I≈øle and Ordinances made and practi≈øed thereupon, directing the manner how the quantities of Wooll, Leather, and other Commodities granted to the I≈øland and Ca≈øtles, ought to be di≈øtributed, to wit, by the ≈øaid Governour, Deputy, Bayliff and Jurats, who thereby are ≈øtrictly injoyned to ≈øee that all Bills or Licen≈øes granted, and Returns thereupon may be regi≈øtred in the Court of Jer≈øey, by the Clark, paying for each onely 10 pence; but contrary thereunto, the ≈øaid Col. Gibbons, (without the privity of the Bayliff and Jurats, or keeping any Regi≈øtring thereof) hath granted Licences for the ≈øaid Commodities, to whom he plea≈øed, re≈øerving for him≈øelf, Allies, and particular friends, not at all related to the I≈øland or Ca≈øtles, the greate≈øt quantity: all which illegall and unju≈øt proceedings, are very much to the prejudice of the State, and to the Marchants and others of that I≈øland: to the State, becau≈øe none could controle nor check him, either in the granting and di≈øpo≈øing of the quantities of the ≈øaid Commodities, although 20 times more then is allotted to the I≈øle and Ca≈øtles, nor in the Returns which he hath made; ≈øo that any part or parcel of Wool or Leather, hath been tran≈øported or connived at by him, to be tran≈øported into France for his advantage; being impo≈ø≈øible to que≈øtion the Tran≈øporters. To the Inhabitants, becau≈øe many of them are denied the benefit of any part of the ≈øaid Licences: And mo≈øt of tho≈øe that have any, it is but by very ≈ømall parcels, as 6, 7, 8, 10, 12, 15, 20, 25, 30, Todds of Wooll, and other Commodities
proportionably; for which he hath ≈øuffered his Clarks to extort from the people one Crown for each Licence, and for the lea≈øt, half a Crown, which amounts to a con≈øiderable ≈øum of money, among≈øt the poor Inhabitants.

2. That the ≈øaid Governour, in order to ≈øatisfie his un≈øatiable avarice, did contrive another unju≈øt way by fleecing the poor Inhabitants, in extorting from tho≈øe that trade out of the I≈øland ≈øix d. per head for a Pa≈ø≈øe: which Pa≈ø≈øe, was to continue but for five dayes; and then, if (by contrary winds) they were ≈øtayed, the ≈øaid Inhabitants were forced to come to the Ca≈øtles, and there take another Pa≈ø≈øe, and pay as they did for the former; and ≈øo con≈øequently, if the wind had not ≈øerved in a moneth or more, having extorted the like from all Boats that went but a fi≈øhing, or fetching at Sea, weed (called ∆≤rack) with which the Inhabitants do ≈øoyl their Lands: which exaction is contrary to the Charters and Priviledges of that I≈øland.

3. That be≈øides tho≈øe forementioned extortions, he the ≈øaid Governour found out a new one, and that very unju≈øt, and di≈øhonourable; (viz.) by appointing ≈øome of his Servants and Souldiers to drive away the ≈øheep of the poor Inhabitants to Mount-Orguil Ca≈øtle, there committing the poor innocent Creatures pri≈øoners, upon pretences of having tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed by entring the Medows of the State. And that in the Winter ≈øea≈øon, and when there is no gra≈ø≈øe, and that all the Cattle is, by the ancient Lawes and Cu≈øtoms of that I≈øle, known not to be kept in at that time, all being then Common, except inclo≈øures, which are kept by ≈øtrong ≈øences: the ≈øaid Servants and Souldiers keeping tho≈øe poor Creatures, (contrary to Law, Cu≈øtoms and Equity) pri≈øoners in the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, till the owners did relea≈øe them, by paying a Ran≈øom for each head, except for tho≈øe that were fat, which the Inhabitants could never find nor redeem again, onely the Skins of ≈øome, having been found, thrown over the walls of the Ca≈øtle of Mount-Orguil.

4. That it is ≈øo apparant, that the ≈øaid Governour hath no other re≈øpects or care, but to advance his particular gain and profit, ≈øhewing the ≈øame very openly, upon a Market day in the I≈øland, when he had the fle≈øh of two, or three, or more, fat Oxen to be ≈øold that day in the Shambles: the Butchers came to him, hearing of a great quantity of Fi≈øh taken the night before, which was coming
to the Market, telling him, that in ca≈øe he ≈øhould ≈øuffer the ≈øaid Fi≈øh to be brought and ≈øold that day, he would lo≈øe a great deal upon the ≈øale of his Beefs: whereupon, the ≈øaid Governour under≈øtanding which way the Cart which brought the ≈øaid Fi≈øh, did come, commanded ≈øome of his Souldiers to ≈øtop it from coming to Market, upon a ≈øeeming pretence, that one third part thereof belonged unto him; but as ≈øoon as the Market was over, he relea≈øed the ≈øaid Fi≈øh, which was a very great lo≈ø≈øe to the owners thereof.

5. That, contrary to Law, and by combination, the ≈øaid Governour hath taken money of per≈øons in that I≈øle, to relea≈øe Leather, which he had cau≈øed to be ≈øeized from them; upon pretence, it was to be tran≈øported for France: and without any legal proceedings, either in declaring it to the Exchequer, or in the Court of that I≈øle, according to the ancient Cu≈øtom, hath of his own Authority, freed the ≈øaid Leather, which afterwards was tran≈øported into France. And namely, from one John Anquetill he received 20 Crowns, or thereabouts. And to relea≈øe Shones and Boots, which his Souldiers had ≈øeized from one John Li≈øcam, twelve Crowns, and afterwards the ≈øaid Boots and Shoos were tran≈øported into France.

6. That about Septemb. 1655. the ≈øaid Governour combined with the owners of a great quantity of Tanned-Leather, which came in a Barque from Waymouth into the Road of the I≈øles, to defraud the State (by pretending the ≈øaid Leather came from Ireland, and was to be tran≈øported to St. Maloes;) but one Scouel Searcher in that I≈øle hearing of it, went aboard the ≈øaid Barque, & finding the ≈øaid Leather to be Engli≈øh, made ≈øeizure of the ≈øame, and pre≈øently acquainted the ≈øaid Governour therewith, who did check the ≈øaid Officer for making ≈øeizure of Leather, which (as he ≈øaid) came out of Ireland: whereupon, the ≈øaid Scouel went again aboard the ≈øaid Barque, carrying with him skilful per≈øons, who knew the difference between Engli≈øh and Iri≈øh tanned Leather, who, after a ≈øtrict ≈øearch and vi≈øit, found the ≈øaid Leather to be Engli≈øh; and although the ≈øaid Scouel returned back to the ≈øaid Governour, acquainting him what further a≈ø≈øurance he had, that it was Engli≈øh Leather; yet the ≈øaid Governour per≈øi≈øted to be more offended at the ≈øaid Officer's diligence, and threatned to lay him
by the heels; and thereupon the ≈øaid Scouel de≈øi≈øted, and the ≈øaid Barque with the ≈øaid Leather, went for St. Maloes, without any further examination, ≈øoon after the ≈øaid Scouel was by the ≈øaid Governour, put out of his place of Searcher: at which proceedings, the ≈øaid Scouel was much di≈øcontented, and gave out, that he would come into England, to complain of the unju≈øt actions of the Governour; but he fearing, le≈øt the ≈øaid Scouel ≈øhould complain, did reimplace him again in his place of Searcher.

7. That the ≈øaid Col. Gibbons, notwith≈øtanding his ≈øaid extortions; and that he is allowed pay of Governour, of Captain of Hor≈øe, and Captain of Foot in that I≈øland, and pay of Colonel, and of Captain of Hor≈øe and Foot in England; be≈øides ≈øeveral gifts and grants of his late Highne≈øs, of other beneficial things in Kent, unto him made and granted; and that he receives his ≈øaid ≈øeveral Salaries out of the Trea≈øury in England: yet ≈øo great is his in≈øatiable avarice & covetou≈øne≈øs, that he is not ≈øatisfied with the ≈øame, but hath received out of the publick Revenue of that I≈øland in money, Wheat, Rents and profits of divers medows and Pa≈øtures, ≈øince the time he fir≈øt came thither, to the value of about 2000 l. ≈øterling; for mo≈øt part of which ≈øum, he hath not accounted at all; and if he hath accounted for any part thereof, he hath had it again allowed unto him out of the Exchequer, upon ≈øome pretended disbur≈øements, for Reparations made to Elizabeth-Ca≈øtle in that I≈øland.

8. That the ≈øaid Governour, forces the ≈øaid Inhabitants of that I≈øle, (at his will and plea≈øure) to come and work at the Ca≈øtle, called Elizabeth: which Ca≈øtle is ≈øurrounded of the Sea, and the coming in and going out of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, very dangerous, unle≈øs the Tides are well ob≈øerved, and that for no Salary; and about needle≈øs Reparations and Fortifications, which have alwayes been pretended nece≈ø≈øary by the form ‚Ä¢ r Governours, as has been by him: but, indeed and in truth, it is onely to have opportunity, to finger the States-money, which hath alwayes been ob≈øerved, to be pocketted up by them ≈øo that the State is put to great wa≈øte, and needle≈øs charges, and the poor people to a great deal of trouble and hazard, by forcing them to work in the Ca≈øtle, (as if they were ab≈øolure ≈ølaves) and that beyond the time u≈øed by the wor≈øt of the former Governours, which was onely during one Tide; ≈øo
cruell beyond them, hath the ≈øaid Governour been again≈øt the poor people; and particularly again≈øt tho≈øe of St. Laurence Pari≈øh, whom he cau≈øed to be kept in at work, during the ≈øpace of two Tydes, it happening thereupon, that when they were going out of the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, in a very ob≈øcure night, five of them were drowned with ≈øome of their Cattel: the death, or rather the murther of tho≈øe per≈øons, having not ≈øo much as been examined, or enquired after, although it be evident, their death was occa≈øioned by the ≈øaid Governour; and ≈øome of the Cattel of tho≈øe poor people, having e≈øcaped drowning, were found next morning by the Ca≈øtle Walls, and ≈øeized by his Souldiers as wrack.

9. That the ≈øaid Governour, contrary to the Lawes and Cu≈øtoms of that I≈øland, and the Rules of Warres, and by his Arbitrary will hath ba≈øtonaded and mi≈ø≈ø-u≈øed, (to the indangering of their lives) ≈øeveral of the Inhabitants, committing them clo≈øe pri≈øoners, keeping them at his will and plea≈øure; and when ≈øeemeth good, relea≈øes them again, and that without the con≈øent or knowledge, either of the Juri≈ødiction of that I≈øle, or Council of Warre. And among≈øt others, one Mr. Clement Gallys, high Con≈øtable of St. Saviour, of above 60 years of Age, and one Abraham Beeket Merchant: both which per≈øons have very much ≈øuffered for their affection and faithfulne≈øs to the Common-wealth of England, by the lo≈ø≈øes of their E≈øtates, long exile, and impri≈øonment; and ≈øeveral others.

10 That upon an Order coming to the ≈øaid I≈øle, to procure Seamen; and the Inhabitants knowing, that anciently, upon mature con≈øiderations had by the Kings of England, of the ≈øcituation of that I≈øle, with the nece≈ø≈øity of rai≈øing and maintaining Fortifications, and Bulwarks round about it, and the con≈øtant Guards by day and night, that the people are obliged at the ≈øaid I≈øle, being ≈øo obnoxious to a potent Neighbour, did upon the≈øe and other weighty Con≈øiderations, by ≈øeveral Charters confirmed in the third year of the late Kings Reign, and ≈øince; by the Council of State-free, and excu≈øe the Inhabitants of that I≈øle from pre≈ø≈øing. And ≈øome Souldiers coming to the Pari≈øh of St. Johns, to pre≈ø≈øe, one of the Inhabitants, by name Francis Marret, who in a civil manner, asked the ≈øaid Souldier, By what Order they would pre≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid Inhabitants: whereupon one of the Souldiers an≈øwered him, he
wold pre≈øently ≈øhew him his Warant, which was by Pi≈øtolling him through the head; (≈øaying, This was his Commi≈ø≈øion, or words to the ≈øame effect) whereof he pre≈øently died. And then fell with his Comerades upon the re≈øt of the Company, cutting and ≈øla≈øhing them. Notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch inhumane murther, proceedings, and cruelties, the ≈øaid Governour made no more inquiry or examination of the fact, than if the ≈øaid Souldiers had killed and ≈øla≈øhed ≈øo many Toads, which indeed was their boa≈øting afterwards.

11. That divers Souldiers and Seamen pretending to have Order to Impre≈ø≈øe per≈øons, went about the I≈øland and ≈øeized upon ≈øeverall young People of good Families, making them believe they ≈øhould be ≈øent to Jamaica; but in ca≈øe they would give them ≈øo much money as they demanded (or rather ran≈øomed them at) they would relea≈øe them: which their Parents and them≈øelves not daring to ask them, by what Order they did ≈øuch things, le≈øt they ≈øhould be dealt withall, as the ≈øaid Maret and others had been: Therefore did choo≈øe rather to part with their money to redeem their Children, then to Complain. Which Barbarous and unchri≈øtian actions, the ≈øaid Governour connived act, without inflicting any puni≈øhment upon the Offenders, although they knew as well the ≈øaid evil practi≈øes as the former.

12. That about the month of January 1655, the Barque Bonadventure of Ier≈øey, John Ahier Ma≈øter, was taken by an O≈øtendor near the ≈øaid I≈øle. The ≈øaid Ahier rather then ≈øuffer the lo≈ø≈øe of all, and to be carryed with many Pa≈ø≈øengers then aboard Captives, did agree with the ≈øaid O≈øtendor for the Redemption of his Ve≈ø≈øel and Goods; whereupon he was ≈øet on Shoare in the ≈øaid I≈øle, to procure the money agreed upon, and to return with ≈øpeed, which he did, and carryed it aboard, and thereupon his ≈øaid Ve≈ø≈øel, Pa≈ø≈øengers, and ≈øo much of the Goods as were left, were freed and brought into the I≈øland; where no ≈øooner he was arrived, but the ≈øaid Governour ≈øent for him, calling the ≈øaid Ahier Traytor, becau≈øe he had carryed money to the enemy, without fir≈øt acquainting him therewith, which he could not do by rea≈øon it was night when he was put a Shoare, and the Tyde up, that none could get into the Ca≈øtle where the ≈øaid Governour was; and being obliged to return with ≈øpeed, the ≈øaid Ahier having by his diligence
redeemed four times more then he carried, notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Governour to revenge him≈øelf of the ≈øaid Ahier, hath refu≈øed to give him Certificats as he doth to others, of the Landing of ≈øuch Goods as were not Rifled by the enemy, into the I≈øland; although the ≈øaid Ahier hath ≈øhewed him Certificats of the Bayliff and Jurats of the I≈øle, and of the Searcher there concerning the truth thereof: which inju≈øtice tends only to endeavour the ruine of the ≈øaid Ahier: who upon the lading at Hampton a quantity of Wooll and Leather, hath given ≈øecurity and bonds of great Sums of money for the Delivery of the ≈øame in Jer≈øey, the ≈øaid Ahier being in danger that the ≈øaid Bonds, for want of ≈øuch Certificats, will be put in pro≈øecution again≈øt him at the Exchequer Court.

13. That the ≈øaid Colonel Gibbons being appointed by the late Protector and Council one of the Commi≈ø≈øioners for compounding with the Inhabitants of that I≈øland, and likewi≈øe Receiver-General, did contrary to his In≈øtructions, and mo≈øt inhumane-like, as ≈øoon as the poor Inhabitants had ≈øubmitted to Compound for their ≈ømall e≈øtates, which (of mo≈øt of them) did not con≈øi≈øt of above 8, 9.10.12.15.20, pound per annum, He the ≈øaid Gibbons would ≈øend to them to bring and pay their fine, which many could not performe at the very in≈øtant, whereupon the ≈øaid Gibbons would not give them further time, but would pre≈øently ≈øend ≈øuch a number of Troopers to their hou≈øes, and there to abide upon free quarter till the poor people had paid in their money, that in ≈øeveral hou≈øes the ≈øaid Troopers did eat and ≈øpoyle more then the fines of the parties amounted unto. And when the ≈øufferers went to complain to the ≈øaid Gibbons of their heavy burthens, he would tell them that his ≈øon and another Souldier would lend them money to pay their ≈øaid fines, and ≈øo remove the ≈øaid Troopers, provided they would enter in bond to repay the ≈øame within ≈øuch time as they ≈øhould limit, and pay him U≈øe for the ≈øame, which proffer many of them were forced (rather than to be utterly ruined) to accept, although the ≈øame were with ≈øuch horrid extortion as never was heard to have been practi≈øed among≈øt the wor≈øt of Barbarians, to wit, 20.25. & 30. per centum, for each month, and yet the ≈øaid mony ≈øo lent, was none of his but of the publique, which he then had in Ca≈øh, or tho≈øe appointed by him.

14. That the ≈øaid Gibbons knowing ≈øuch Tyrannical proceedings, were directly contrary to all Law, Ju≈øtice, or Equity, and apprehending that the ≈øame would be repre≈øented in England, did forbid that any per≈øon ≈øhould depart the I≈øle without his Pa≈ø≈øe, or any to ≈øend or carry Letters without fir≈øt bringing them to him to peru≈øe. And be≈øides, the ≈øaid Gibbons cau≈øed all Ve≈ø≈øels to be ≈øearched for Letters which were bound for England, upon which ≈øearch one Letter of Mr. Philip Maret was intercepted as it was ≈øending into England, directed to a Captain that hath alwayes been in the Parliament Army, and a great a≈ø≈øertor of the Good Old Cau≈øe, which Letter was occa≈øioned by rea≈øon of the notorious Tyrannies of the ≈øaid Gibbons, therein fully detected, but particularly of his unju≈øt dealings again≈øt ≈øeveral well-affected per≈øons of that I≈øland, who although innocent he did not exempt from compounding no more then the ≈øaid Maret who had very deeply ≈øuffered under the enemy, by being declared Traytor by them, and who ≈øeized and ≈øeque≈øtred his E≈øtate, by rea≈øon the ≈øaid Maret was in the Parliament quarters, at, and after the late King was put to death; for the Redemption of his E≈øtate he was forced to pay to the Enemy a con≈øiderable ≈øum of money. Upon which interception the ≈øaid Gibbons committed the ≈øaid Maret clo≈øe Pri≈øoner in Mout-orguill: Ca≈øtle, where he kept him 16 months together (mo≈øt part of the time) without Pen, Ink, or Paper, or communication with his Friends, being there u≈øed very B ‚Ä¢ rbarou≈øly: After which time the ≈øaid Gibbons relea≈øed him upon Bayl, and then the ≈øaid Maret came for England, to complain and endeavour to have redre≈ø≈øe: which the ≈øaid Gibbons di≈øcovering, told the ≈øaid Maret if he would referre the whole bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to him, he would free him from his troubles, which the ≈øaid Maret accepted, by rea≈øon he ob≈øerved the ≈øaid Gibbons to be very potent at Court, but in lieu of doing according as he had engaged, he the ≈øaid Gibbons attempted by ≈øureptitious ways to have the E≈øtate of the ≈øaid Maret to be forfeited, who for two years together hath waited in London upon the ≈øaid Gibbons, being thereby very much damnified as well in his bodily health as e≈øtate, which Impri≈øonment and troubles hath almo≈øt brought his antient and weakly Mother to the grave.

div.head: Articles of mi≈ødemeanours, exhibited again≈øt Cap. Rich. Yeardley, Deputy Governour of the I≈øle of Jer≈øey.
div.p: 15. THat the ≈øaid Captain Richard Yeardley as Deputy Governour, hath for the≈øe late years, contrary to the priviledges granted to the people of that I≈øle, taken upon him≈øelf to di≈øpo≈øe of the Licen≈øes of Wooll, Leather, and other Commodities granted and allotted to the ≈øaid I≈øle, to whom he ≈øeemeth good; and for his particular gain and advantage, doth ingro≈ø≈øe a great part of the ≈øaid Commodities to him≈øelf, by granting Licen≈øes to his Servants, Allies, Factors and others, not in the lea≈øt related to the ≈øaid I≈øle, to the great prejudice and dammage of Merchants and others Inhabitants of that I≈øle, among≈øt whom, and of right, the ≈øaid Licen≈øes ought to be di≈øtributed; by which unju≈øt proceedings, ≈øeveral of the ≈øaid Merchants and Inhabitants, are forced to buy the ≈øaid Licen≈øes from the ≈øaid ≈øtrangers, at very high rates; it being evident, and of certain truth, that a great quanting of the ≈øaid Commodities, are for his Accounts, and of his Factors and Agents, tran≈øported into France, which cannot be hindered, by rea≈øon that none can, or dare controle him, either in the di≈øpo≈øing the ≈øaid Licen≈øes, or in making and giving Returns for the ≈øeveral Commodities as he doth, and ≈øeemeth be≈øt for his advantage, all being at his arbitrary will and di≈øpo≈øal; But directly contrary and again≈øt the ancient way practi≈øed in the di≈øpo≈øall of the ≈øaid Licen≈øes; which are to be di≈øtributed in the pre≈øence of the Bayliff and Ju≈øtices there, and regi≈øtred in the Court by the Clark, and that for ten pence per Licence, whereas the ≈øaid Yeardly ≈øuffers his Clark to take of the poor Inhabitants five ≈øhillings, or at lea≈øt two and ≈øix pence for every Licence, although but for five todds of wooll.

16. That the ≈øaid Yeardly contrary to the Law and antient priviledges of the ≈øaid I≈øle, and contrary to the Law of War, hath
by his arbitrary will and plea≈øure Impri≈øoned, and afterwards relea≈øed divers of the Inhabitants, namely, one Mr. Ph. Richar≈øon, and la≈øtly, the High Con≈øtable, and other Officers of the Pari≈øh of St. Brefade, onely for executing the Duty of their places, in ≈øearching a ≈øu≈øpected Hou≈øe of the Parri≈øh (where lived one of his Souldiers) for divers Sheep, and other things that had been ≈øtollen from ≈øome of the inhabitants: And that onely by rea≈øon that it was a Souldier's Hou≈øe; as if Souldiers hou≈øes were Sanctuaries, and not to be ≈øearched.

17. That the ≈øaid Yeardly very well knowing that by the E≈øtabli≈øhment of Jer≈øey, and for the defence thereof, there ought to be kept twenty Troopers furni≈øhed with Hor≈øes, for which number there is con≈øtant pay allowed from the Common-wealth; and yet the ≈øaid Yeardly (Commander in Chief there) connives and ≈øuffers the Common-wealth to be defrauded, (and the I≈øland indangered) by not keeping above twelve Troopers that have Hor≈øes ≈øerviceable. Some of the Troopers which are in pay having never a Hor≈øe, and others that have are no way ≈øerviceable; ≈øuffering Servants and Children of eleven years of age to be mu≈øtered, and Pay allowed to their Ma≈øters for the ≈øaid Servants and Children.

18. That the ≈øaid Captain Yeardly to the very much indangering the ≈øafety of the Ca≈øtles, and of that I≈øle ≈øo con≈øiderable to the Common-wealth, doth ≈øuffer Souldiers to be lifted in foot Companies that were in actual war in that I≈øle again≈øt the Common-wealth of England.

19. That the ≈øaid Captain Richard Yeardly, Deputy Governor of the ≈øaid I≈øle, contrary to the Laws of War, and to the great Scandal of the Government of the Army, and godly people in that I≈øle, and ill example to others, doth keep con≈øtant Company with the mo≈øt notorious Cavalliers of that I≈øle, going often to their hou≈øes there to play at Cards, to fea≈øt and drink healths in ≈øuch exce≈ø≈øive manner, that ≈øeveral times the ≈øaid Yeardly hath ben ob≈øerved to be ≈øo much di≈øtempered with Liquor, and ≈øo drunk, that he could not ≈øcarce go or ≈øtand.
20. That the ≈øaid Yeardly hath ≈øeveral times vowed, if he ≈øhould remain in the ≈øaid I≈øle, he would take ≈øuch cour≈øe that all the Anabapti≈øts there ≈øhould be bani≈øhed the I≈øle.

21. That it is here credibly informed that the ≈øaid Captain Richard Yeardly before and ≈øince the di≈ø≈øolving of the late A≈ø≈øembly, did appear very much di≈øatisfied of the proceedings of tho≈øe called Commonwealth men, then ≈øitting in the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øembly, ≈øaying, that they were all for Charles Stuart. And after the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øembly was di≈ø≈øolved, he did appear very much di≈øcontented and di≈ø≈øatisfied of the ≈øame, muttering again≈øt the proceedings of the Army, and pleading openly again≈øt them and their actions; and for the late Protectors Government, with whom he was the night before the ≈øaid Di≈ø≈øolution.

22. That the ≈øaid Captin Richard Yeardly is ≈øuch a Countenancer of Notorious Cavaliers in that I≈øle, that when any well-affected per≈øons have a Suite or Action at Law again≈øt them in any thing con≈øiderable, then the ≈øaid Yeardly upon the day of tryal or hearing of the Cau≈øe was ≈øure to come to the Court, and ≈øo effectually countenanced the Cau≈øe of ≈øuch Cavaliers again≈øt the well-affected, yt by his high words & threathings, he did awe the Court in ≈øuch manner that the well-affected per≈øons could not have Ju≈øtice: And particularly, about the month of October la≈øt, he appeared for one grand Malignant whom he calls Sr. Ph. Carteret, again≈øt two known well-affected per≈øons, (by name) Mr. Thomas Roberts, and Mr. John Ricard, who both of them have much ≈øuffered for their affection, to the renowned long Parliament of England, who did then ≈øue the ≈øaid Carteret in Court, by vertue of a certain Ordinance of Parliament dated the 16th of September 1645. The ≈øaid well-affected per≈øons being then railed again≈øt, and accu≈øed as if they had been guilty of high Trea≈øon, to plead again≈øt the ≈øaid Delinquent; and the ≈øaid Roberts then Lievtenant of the Train Band of St. Owens Parri≈øh, and the ≈øaid Ricard En≈øigne, were both di≈ømi≈ø≈øed that day from their Commands, by the ≈øaid Yeardly; for no other offence (known to them) but for pleading again≈øt a Notorious Malignant.

23. That the ≈øaid Captain Yeardly being Authorized in that I≈øle a Commi≈ø≈øioner to have an in≈øpection upon ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhould be made choyce of by the People to be Ju≈øtices: He the ≈øaid Yeardly would rather admit, and cau≈øe to be admitted, ≈øome that had been in Arms again≈øt the Parl. to the place of Judicature, then to permitt tho≈øe which had bin cho≈øen, and had bin great ≈øufferers for
the Parliaments Intere≈øt, to be admitted in the ≈øaid place of Judicature.

24. The≈øe high Mi≈ødemeanours committed and connived at by the ≈øaid Col. Rob. Gibbons, Gove ‚Ä¢ nour as afore≈øaid, and the ≈øaid Yeardley his Deputy, with more of that nature, can be ≈øufficiently proved, in ca≈øe certain per≈øons of integrity and hone≈øty, (having neither relation to the ≈øaid Gibbons, nor to the I≈øle, and ≈øuch as the ≈øaid Governor may not be a terrour to, as he is to the poor innocent people there) might go thither with power & authority, not onely to examine the truth of the ≈øaid Mi≈ødemeanours, but likewi≈øe all other grievances of the people: and either to authorize them to reform the ≈øame, and ≈øee that the Offendors may receive condigne puni≈øhment for tho≈øe enormous and foul Crimes, according to the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of that I≈øle; or at lea≈øt, to make their Report upon the whole matter formerly, as upon ≈øuch complaint, was practi≈øed in Ca≈øes of the like nature.
